Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2014 02:20PM lekker wrote: Papillon - I tried to read through the whole thread but I might've missed something.  You said that you met with several doctors - did you ever have a pedigree done by a genetic counselor?  Oncologists don't always know a lot about genetics (according to my second opinion onc who's an MD/PhD in microbiology).  Have you told any of the doctors about your paternal family history?  There is an online BRCA risk calculator that will take into account both sides of your family history here www.afcri.upenn.edu/itacc/penn2/   The comment that your mother's breast cancer cannot be hereditary was painfully ignorant.  Most medical professionals used to believe that breast cancer was never hereditary - until Mary Claire King and her team discovered BRCA1. As others have mentioned, there are several other known genetic mutations with links to breast cancer.  I've been tested for almost all of them and not because of a strong family history of breast cancer, rather because of a personal history of multiple cancers that both presented at a young age (two indicators of a possible genetic basis for the cancers). When I went through the testing process, my genetic counselor first ordered BRCA testing but only for the three founder mutations most commonly found in the Ashkenazi Jewish population (my dad's side). When those results came in, my GC said "congratulations - you're negative". I insisted on the full BRCA sequencing plus BART and she approved.  When that came back negative, I met with a geneticist (MD) who examined me for external signs of other genetic syndromes (several have things like large skulls, freckles on the lips and gums, and other unusual traits).  She didn't find anything.  I asked for the Broca panel from the University of Washington (developed by Mary Claire King) and it was approved.  It also came back negative - I didn't have a single mutation in any of the 40 genes.  So I am another uninformed negative.  I feel like I either have an as-yet undiscovered mutation, or I was exposed to some environmental toxin that didn't hurt my brother or my parents, or I just have terrible luck.  I already did the most aggressive surgeries (BMX and hyst/ooph).  I go for annual skin checks and have frequent colonoscopies so I am being proactive where I can.  Some people might wonder if it really matters if there's a genetic basis since I've already done all I can do.  When people ask me that, I show them pictures of my little girls.  My greatest hope is that I eventually find a mutation that caused this for me - then my daughters can choose to test for it and we can all celebrate when they get a true negative.  Because if that doesn't happen, they will have to start colonoscopies at 20 and breast screening in their early thirties, and I'd like to spare them that.
Posts.Title: Is there a type which is 100% not hereditary?.. Papillon1 Papillon1

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2016 10:35AM lekker wrote: Mine was grade 2 from the core needle biopsy and grade 1 after surgery so it can be downgraded too. I hope your surgery goes well

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2015 08:33AM lekker wrote: Sorry that you have to join us. One thing you might consider - asking about neoadjuvant (before surgery) endocrine therapy. This is sometimes done to try to shrink a tumor before surgery, but in your case maybe it could be used to safely delay surgery until after New Years. With hormone receptor positive ILC, you will most likely be prescribed tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor (with ovarian suppression if premenopausal) after surgery so it might be possible.

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2016 01:45PM lekker wrote: https://www.genome.gov/10002328/genetic-discrimination-fact-sheet/ You're right. Life insurance, long term care insurance and disability insurance are not covered under the federal genetic non-discrimination (GINA) laws. The federal laws only protect employment and health insurance. Read more in the link I provided.
Posts.Title: Could my life insurance get denied if I go for genetic testing? maiyen maiyen

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2017 01:16PM lekker wrote: I strongly recommend you find a licensed genetic counselor to consult regarding genetic testing. A LCG would ask you questions about your personal and family histories and tell you what, if any, testing would be appropriate. A LGC would also explain the pros and cons of testing, what insurance can be impacted by a positive result, etc. There are many complex issues associated with testing and it's important that you understand all of them before making a decision. One point to consider now is that, when applicable, it is always preferable to test the individual with cancer (known as the proband) rather than his or her relatives who have not been diagnosed with cancer.
Posts.Title: Reasons to get genetic testing? jillybeantabby lekker

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2013 09:29PM lekker wrote: I know it's hard to let others help, but try to think of it this way... You give people a gift when you let them help you. As it makes you feel good to take care of others, realize that they will get pleasure from taking care of you. For me in the beginning, the biggest help was when people would take my kids for fun play dates while I was researching, attending appointments, etc. After my two most grueling appointments (RO and second opinion MO), the friends who watched my girls also kept them through dinner so my husband and I could go for a nice meal (and cocktails!) and decompress before picking them up - invaluable! After my last three surgeries, one friend scheduled meals to be delivered each day for two or three weeks. Other friends drove my kids to school and activities. Others took them for sleepovers. All of it made the past year bearable for me, tolerable for my kids and husband and made the people who stepped in feel like they were making a difference in keeping a family afloat - because they were!
Posts.Title: My daughters tears are killing me.... soccermomof4 lekker

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2013 10:58PM lekker wrote: I had the Broca testing after BRCA came back negative, too. There were no mutations found for me. My HMO was willing to pay for it because I had a personal history of colon cancer at 30 and pre-menopausal breast cancer at 42. I've said in many posts that any suspicion of a genetic basis for cancer should be discussed with a licensed genetic counselor. As Melissa has said, there are times when syndromes other than BRCA should be tested first. Melissa - were you tested for the mutations that cause Lynch Syndrome? The classic Lynch cancers are colon and uterine, but there are several others. My GC had the lab pull my old colon polyp and run an IHC test as a first step in my process as Lynch was her first suspicion. That particular test isn't 100% especially with an in situ cancer like mine but Lynch was definitively ruled out thanks to the Broca panel. This is all in its infancy and many doctors have no training or education that qualifies them to request or refuse tests. My GC had me examined by a geneticist to look for signs of any of the other known syndromes before they authorized the Broca. Stick with a GC to start the process.
Posts.Title: Negative for BRACA gene, but had strong family history julieho SexyC430

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2014 12:13PM lekker wrote: The title of this thread is Ki-67 score vs. Oncotype. No one with a tumor that overexpresses HER2 would ever have the oncotype done so please take that out of this thread. AA - it is possible that a similar test could eventually be developed to help drive treatment decisions for HER2 patients, but it is not relevant to this particular discussion.   Nancy - you asked about calculating risk using the oncotype, but forgoing endocrine therapy.  Oncotype is calculated by looking at the expression of 16 genes (and 5 reference genes) - I posted the details in a thread about progesterone blocking drugs (don't have link right now but I will post it later as I think it's relevant here).  If your score is high because your ER group gene expression is low (basically you are "barely" ER/PR positive or even negative by their measure), you might not get as much benefit from endocrine therapy.  Genomic Health doesn't tell us the 16 individual calculations that make up our Recurrence Risk Score, but they do tell us their ER, PR and HER2 scores (because those are currently the only "actionable" measures on their own).  The lower the ER (and possibly PR, but that's a discussion for another thread), the lower your benefit from endocrine therapy.  You can have a high oncotype even with high ER/PR expression because of the other genes (proliferation and invasion) and in that case I would think endocrine therapy would be extremely important.  You can look at your report to see your individual ER and PR scores - if they are really high, maybe you could discuss with your doctor what your options are (clinical trial for a new endocrine therapy, or off label use of other approved drugs, etc). MameMe - I'm very sorry to hear of your progression.  From reading your story, I feel like you blame yourself for not continuing with endocrine therapy when you were diagnosed the first two times.  I don't mean to overstep, but please be gentle with yourself.  One thing oncotype shows is how many women progress even with tamoxifen (and chemo). I had a low score of 13 which means that 9 out of every 100 women with my similar tumor profile were stage IV within 10 years even with tamoxifen.  I hope you have a long run with taxol and better experience with tamoxifen/AIs this time if you try them again.
Posts.Title: Ki-67 score vs. Oncotype neugirl Jewel259

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2014 11:16AM lekker wrote: Below is my post from the progesterone thread.  You can see how genomic health uses Ki-67 as one of the 16 calculations.  One thing I think is critical to remember when considering issues like this is that the pathologist (who would be the one to assign a Ki-67 measurement if done as well as ER, PR and HER2) is using a different tumor sample than genomic health would be using. Cancer is a heterogenous disease - it's not impossible to have very different results within the same tumor.  Back to the old but original reason for this thread, the OP was concerned because her pathology didn't mention Ki-67 and that made her feel that she wasn't given all of the information she needed to make the chemo/no chemo decision.  I too felt shorted because my pathology didn't mention Ki-67 but eventually realized that the oncotype test did measure it - as well as 4 other proliferation genes.  Like the OP, I had to be convinced not to do chemo because I wanted to do everything possible to avoid a recurrence. Once I understood that chemo doesn't guarantee a cure and it has its own risks to consider, I agreed that the right plan for me was to forego it.   Here's my post... the PR score is just one of the factors that goes into calculating the oncotype score. They break down the different genes into groups and multiply each group by a factor they somehow came up with to get the final score. PR is in the "ER related genes" group which is the only group to have a negative multiplier - the higher that group's score, the more it lowers the final result. So if you have low or absent PR expression, it will raise that part of the score. If the scores from the other groups are low, you can still end up with a low score of course - PR is just one piece of the puzzle.  The test was then validated using 675 node negative ER positive tamoxifen treated cases from NSABP B-14. In this analysis given classes of genes were given previously determined weighting factors and prognostic scores were calculated. The weightings would seem to make sense with proliferation, Her2 related, and invasion group genes increasing the score and ER related genes decreasing the score. The score was a continuous variable, but for the convenience of the presentation the patients were divided into 3 groups using cut points of 18 and 31.
Posts.Title: Ki-67 score vs. Oncotype neugirl Jewel259

I don't mean to put you on the spot, but I'm curious.  My hospital didn't mention Ki-67 on my pathology either.

They pulled the polyp to test it for indicators of Lynch Syndrome. Can you imagine working in that warehouse??
Posts.Title: Ki67 testing and BC risk momoschki MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2014 12:57PM lekker wrote: Were you prescribed antibiotics back in December when the doctor told you it was mastitis?  You mentioned that it got a little better in December and January.  If you took antibiotics in December, that might explain why you felt better for a while.  If that's the case, it sounds like you might need an additional course of antibiotics (possibly a different medication than you took the first time).  The "dent" and wrinkle you mention should be photographed if possible.  Also write down when it happens and what it looks like to see if there's a pattern that follows your milk production.  Do you really feel that your left side is "overproducing"?  Your baby is 14 months old - I would think your body is producing exactly what your baby needs by this time.  Yes, you only feed from one side but lots of women end up doing that - and what about mothers of multiples?  Just because it's coming from only one side shouldn't mean that you're "over" producing to the point that your breast is deformed.  Also, you said this started in December but you've been feeding from just the one side for over a year - again, how would that be related to production if you've been doing it that way for so long with no previous problem?  I'm not trying to alarm you, but your doctor's comments don't make a lot of sense to me (I'm not a doctor).  I think you're smart to follow up on this.  Yes, our breasts go through a lot of changes during lactation but you know your body best.  You said something about pumping - do you direct feed as well as pump?  If so, maybe try cutting back on the pumping (if you can spare the milk) and see if it helps while you're waiting to see the doctor again?
Posts.Title: Worried about ibc. Scaredtoronto lekker

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2014 11:46AM lekker wrote: Do you have your report from genomic health?  By looking at their measurement of ER, PR and HER2, you can get an idea of why your score was low or high.  For example, my ER was lower on oncotype vs. pathology, but my PR was really high on oncotype.  Those scores combined with a low level (but not absent) HER2 score makes me think that my invasion and proliferation sub-scores had to be quite low to get a final score of 13.  Your signature line says you're PR negative, which can raise your score (see the way they calculate the final score in my post above). If in your final report you have high ER and PR and low HER2 sub-scores, but a high overall score, it would be a result of high invasion and/or proliferation sub-scores.  When someone makes a decision about chemo based solely on Ki-67, they are only looking at one tiny piece of the puzzle.  Oncotype looks at Ki-67 as well as 4 other markers of proliferation and does so within the context of the tumor's hormone profile, HER2 expression and invasion likelihood.  It's not a perfect test - after all it still can only tell you your risk stratification and possible response to chemo.  It doesn't tell you if you will recur or not or if chemo will work for you (or harm you).  Now those are tests I'd love to see!

Posts.Title: What is fatty hilum? mawhinney MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2013 12:40AM lekker wrote: I've spent a lot of time researching genetic cancer issues and my opinion that time spent with a (good) genetic counselor can be very valuable. He or she can help you create a detailed family tree and find clues to a possible genetic basis for your (or your family's) cancer/s. While BRCA 1 and 2 mutations cause the majority of known genetic breast cancers, there are several other genes that could be the culprit. Cowden's Syndrome (PTEN) was mentioned in an earlier post - there are some very specific external markers of Cowden's and in the absence of those, it would indeed be very strange for a genetic counselor to suspect that. There are also multiple versions of the Myriad Genetics BRCA tests - if you have Ashkenazi Jewish background, they might possibly only test you for the three founder mutations most commonly found in that group. That test is only a few hundred dollars and is also included in the commercially available 23 and me test for only $99. When my genetic counselor initially told me I was BRCA negative, I asked for the written report and saw that they only ran this most basic test. I asked for and received the full sequencing and BART tests and they were also negative. Because I had a stage 0 colorectal cancer at age 30 and ILC at 42, there's a strong suspicion of a genetic component to my cancers so the next step was the Broca (sounds similar to BRCA but is actually the name of a doctor) panel out of U. Of Washington that fully sequences 40 "oncogenes". This test takes 12 weeks to get results so I will be waiting until May. My advice to you is to try to get as many details about your family as possible - for cancer, try to find out age and stage at diagnosis, what specific type, etc. Ask about high blood pressure, diabetes, cardiac disease, benign growths and conditions that seem to run in your family, etc. Some hereditary cancer syndromes have distinct benign conditions that go along with them so it's good to mention everything that seems common in your family. The truth is that while we can sequence the entire human genome, we still only understand very small pieces of it. We are all mutants, but only some of those mutations will ever cause a problem (and some are actually protective) - we only know a few of the troublemakers. The genetic counselor should be able to explain what the test can tell you (and what it cannot) and possibly identify tests other than BRCA that might be useful for you. I wish you all the best.
Posts.Title: BRAC test, initial consultation? Papillon1 Papillon1

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2017 12:16PM lekker wrote: Louise - your tumor is tiny but it's already figured out how to travel to the nodes. Would you consider trying an AI and you can always stop if the side effects are worse than the potential benefit you might gain? Just something to consider.
Posts.Title: ILC 1mm - Benefits of Hormone Treatment? Louise-Skippy lekker

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2014 07:14PM lekker wrote: Mischief - I think it's now standard to take out the tubes when doing either an ooph or hysterectomy since it appears that many ovarian cancers start in the tubes.  I had cervix, uterus, tubes and ovaries taken at 43. My MO thought it was over treatment but my gyn onc thought it was totally reasonable with my history.  Along with colon and breast cancers, I was having horrible periods every other week that left me needing iron infusions before surgery.  I could've tried a uterine ablation or maybe attempted removing or embolizing my fibroids, but it didn't want to mess with them - a very tiny percentage of fibroids are actually sarcoma in disguise.  All of the women on my mother's side have had surgical menopause in their 40s and no one has had cardiac issues.  I elected to stay on tamoxifen for at least a few years to help my bones - and to hold on to whatever estrogen my adrenals and fat can make.  It's a very personal decision and no one can say what's best for you - even the doctors!
Posts.Title: Should I get a prophylactic oophorectomy? surfette Brip1geneticmutation

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2013 02:32PM lekker wrote: I would never question another woman's treatment decisions any more than I would tolerate someone questioning mine. Doctors need to give us all of the facts, let us decide for ourselves and then back away. The truth is that there isn't a doctor alive that can guarantee any of us what our outcomes will be - they can only give us risk calculations and tell us about the potential benefits of any given treatment/surgery. With an Oncotype score of 13 I was advised by three docs not to do chemo, but my primary MO said he'd support me if I chose to do it anyway and it was ultimately up to me. I'm sorry but I forgot to go to medical school - why the heck would anyone let me make that decision? Ultimately he knew that I'm the one who has to live with my decisions and he knew he couldn't make any promises either way. I knew from the very beginning that I wanted a BMX but I had a LX first as all the docs thought I would do great with that and rads. They might very well have been right - there's no way to know. My prophy side was benign "with fibrocystic change" but I had already had 3 lumps removed from that side over the years - the first at 17 (no one thought it was cancer but it was over 5cm and they thought it might hide things down the road). The cancer side had multiple areas of PLCIS as well as an additional tiny 2.5mm invasive tumor - none of which showed up on the MRI. Was it over treatment? You tell me. Until they find a way to identify which tumors are dangerous and which aren't, until they find a way to tell you if you're cured surgically or you have breast cancer cells currently circulating trying to find a home, until there's a cure... "over treatment" is not hysteria - it's as valid a choice as any other. After all, how will you ever know if you would've had a different outcome with different treatment decisions? The answer is that you never will. No matter what choices you made as you were thrown into the vortex of a breast cancer diagnosis, please try to be at peace with those decisions. You did the best you could with the information you had at the time. There's nothing more any of us (including the oncologists) could've done.
Posts.Title: Listen to your gut WannaCruize AnnBR

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2014 09:29PM lekker wrote: Waiting for results like yours is just awful.  It might take a while for you to get a call as they will probably review and compare the bone scan to the pet (so it's more complicated than just getting the results of one test alone) before talking to you.  Disc issues can sometimes light up a bone scan because it's common to have degenerative bone changes along with the disc.  There are other benign things that can show up that May or may not have anything to do with your previous disc issue (facet arthrosis, etc). I'm not trying to disrespect your fears - just trying to encourage you that your tech's comment isn't a diagnosis.  Avail yourself (safely) of the Xanax as needed for now.  I hope you get good news soon!

Meals, cleaning, errands, helping take care of your child, taking you for pampering sessions - whatever might make you feel a little better. Keep us posted!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, 20 weeks pregnant SkiChick86 lekker

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2013 06:06PM lekker wrote: I'm not petite but 5'5" and slim with B cups to start. I have incisions from lateral (outside) side of breast to nipple from my NSSBMX. The incisions were dictated by my prior lumpectomy. I was under for 5.5 hours for the mastectomy and TE placement. I think the time and incisions are dependent on your PS more than your size. If a dr says that he/she can only put an incision in one specific place, it might very well be that it is the only place that he/she knows how to do it, not that there's a limitation because of your size or the location of the tumor. If you don't like your PS' approach, you might want to find another surgeon, or at least get another opinion. Each dr tends to do what he/she is comfortable with and rarely is open to something else. This is not a criticism - doctors can only do so much and master only so many techniques. Someone who is an expert with alloderm and immediate implants would offer that but someone who only uses TE's and round implants might not want to try - nor would you want them to. I found it very frustrating to try to make these decisions as I never considered cosmetic implants before my diagnosis so I knew nothing about the process. It sounds like you have very specific desires for your outcome so I encourage you to find a surgeon who can make it a reality for you. Have you posted to the implant sizing 101 forum yet? Even though it's for women with TE's already, Whippetmom is really helpful with some of these issues and I encourage you to check it out. You could probably pm her with your concerns and see what she thinks.
Posts.Title: Duration of PBMX surgery on a petite woman? BlueSky5 sarahjane7374

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2017 04:43PM lekker wrote: I can understand why you're feeling overwhelmed with all of this. I had comprehensive genetic testing because I had a malignant colon polyp removed at age 30 and invasive lobular breast cancer at 42. No mutations were found but I chose to have a hysterectomy and oophorectomy at 43. No further cancer was found after that surgery but I'm glad I did it. They will look at all tissue removed during your surgery so hopefully instead of a cancer diagnosis, you can be reassured that there was no cancer there! And while the odds are in your favor for the breast biopsy, I can understand why you're nervous. We are here's to support you each step of the way. You also might try googling for Lynch support boards as there aren't whole lot of members here who post about that. Please keep us posted!

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2014 11:22PM lekker wrote: Cypher - the guidelines your onc is referring to indicate that routine scans for early stagers **** in the absence of symptoms **** has been shown to offer no survival benefit.  The emphasis on absence of symptoms is mine.  In general, having a personal history of breast cancer, especially one at high risk of recurrence, and symptoms like bone pain, pulmonary issues, neurological problems, etc. should raise red flags and be investigated more thoroughly than you would for someone who hasn't already had cancer.

Posts.Title: Oncotype Dx Test Anyone? Warrior_Woman Jojo0529

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2014 08:52PM - edited Jan 14, 2014 08:54PM by lekker Waiting for testing and results is difficult in any situation, but you've already had to hear the words "you have cancer"  in your past. There are no words I can say to make the waiting easier.  You are doing all you can to investigate the lumps and another couple weeks shouldn't make a difference.  If you have any additional symptoms or changes, be sure to let your doctor know so she can decide if it's significant.  Because of your situation as a cancer survivor (I love how you say you "just" had a hysterectomy at 29 - I know you mean you didn't need chemo or whatever but it's still a big deal), it's understandable that this is causing you severe anxiety.  Could you ask your doctor for some anxiety meds to help you through the waiting?  Or explain that the stress this is causing you isn't manageable and you need to get in sooner?  Edited to add...  Are you still under the care of an oncologist?  Dealing with possible recurrences and/or new primaries is a survivorship issue and maybe your onc can get you imaged sooner.
Posts.Title: Just need to get off my chest deenewme AZ85048

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2014 11:50PM lekker wrote: My ER and PR were both 90-95%+ from my biopsy but my oncotype showed a slightly lower ER by their measurement.  The definition of Her2+ Is 3+ By IHC for determining the use of Herceptin (although there are trials going on looking at whether or not Her2 "low" would also benefit) but the oncotype looks to see if there's any expression of Her2 as a measure of aggressiveness.  Even though my ER was lower than expected and my Her2 score was higher, my overall score was 13 - I think because my PR was so high. No one really understands the relevance of PR in all of this yet.

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2017 01:21PM - edited Jan 7, 2017 01:22PM by lekker Sorry you're here! I was following your posts as you went through testing and I was really hoping you'd get good news. You can search these boards to find members who've dealt with BC while pregnant. Then you can try to private message them to build up a support team who really understand your situation. As far as genetic testing goes, it might be worthwhile to at least have a consult with a licensed genetic counselor to talk about options. There are more known harmful mutations out there than just BRCA 1 and 2. I had 40 different genes tested 4 years ago (the Broca panel from the University of Washington)
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, 20 weeks pregnant SkiChick86 lekker

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2017 04:50PM - edited Jan 7, 2017 04:52PM by lekker It's estimated that 6% to 10% of breast cancer patients present as metastatic at initial diagnosis (de novo) so it is pretty rare. I know that it is very difficult not to think the worst, but try not to get ahead of yourself. The early days of diagnosis when you don't have a treatment plan in place are the worst. It seems like it takes forever to get test results only to feel like you have to make immediate decisions - the ultimate case of "hurry up and wait". Your situation is made all the more stressful by your pregnancy. Find a medical team that you really trust and let them guide you through the process. And keep coming back for support here! We are on your side. (Edited many times because my keyboard kept changing that last sentence.).

I had cancer in the other breast at 42 and pathology from my BMX showed only "fibrocystic change" (benign) in the lumpy breast.

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2013 07:01PM lekker wrote: Lymph nodes can be enlarged for many benign reasons (infection is just one) and size is only one attribute that would be considered when deciding whether or not to suggest a biopsy. Other factors that would be weighed are shape, orientation to the surrounding fat, borders, absence or presence of a fatty hylum, blood flow on color Doppler ultrasound, etc. Maybe an ultrasound would give you a non-invasive way to get more information.
Posts.Title: Lymph node seen on mammogram holly123 Zeeba

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2014 10:17PM lekker wrote: Dee it's great that you've been proactive with your health.  Of course you're going to find women here who just "knew" they had cancer from the beginning.  But if you read through the not diagnosed but worried threads, you'll find dozens (hundreds?) of posts from women who were convinced they had cancer only to get a benign result from a biopsy.  Please try to take this one step at a time (I know firsthand that this is easier said than done!). You said you have 4 children and I'm assuming they're all pretty young. Try to find some fun, silly things to do with them - anything that could possibly distract you as you wait.
Posts.Title: Just need to get off my chest deenewme AZ85048

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2014 09:17PM lekker wrote: When I picked up my OncotypeDX paperwork from my onc back in August 2012, I was disappointed that Genomic Health only discloses the ER, PR and Her2 portions of their analysis.  I called Genomic Health and spoke with a rather rude man who told me that the rest of the information that was used to calculate the recurrence score was their proprietary information and is not released.  When I said that they advertise the test as a 16 gene analysis but it seemed strange that they only tell the patient the result of 3, he shut me down and said that there was nothing he could do. I don't know if that's changed in the past year though.
Posts.Title: Oncotype Dx Test Anyone? Warrior_Woman Jojo0529

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2013 10:16PM lekker wrote: I think you have enough cancer in your family history to at least speak with a licensed genetic counselor. He/she will be able to advise you what, if any, testing might be worthwhile for you. If you test positive for a harmful gene mutation, the GC would then advise you about how to go about informing family members so they could consider testing.
Posts.Title: Genetic testing question mermaid18 Beesie

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2017 10:42AM lekker wrote: Extranodal just means that the cancer broke outside of the lymph node. This alone does not mean that it is in your organs or bones, but it's a good idea for them to scan you to be certain. I'm sure there are survival statistics out there for similar cases to yours but you have to remember that you are an individual, not a statistic. And many statistics out there were calculated before herceptin which is a very effective treatment. Perjeta is often also used here in the US for HER2+ disease. Is that available for you too? Please keep coming back for support and to let us know how your scans go.
Posts.Title: What does 'Extranodal extension present' mean? Jaynina Jaynina

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2013 06:32PM lekker wrote: I'm glad you received a very low score! In your case, the OncotypeDX wouldn't normally have been ordered if you truly had a tubular carcinoma. Usually tumors of low grade, "special type" (including tubular), node negative and under 1cm would not receive chemo per NCCN guidelines so there would be no reason to order the test.

Posts.Title: Just need to get off my chest deenewme AZ85048

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2014 12:29AM lekker wrote: Wallycat - actually some people do have their colon removed prophylactically.  Carriers of a mutation for Familial  Adenomatous Polyposis for example.  People with lower penetrance mutations, like Lynch Syndrome, might also do it but colonoscopies are actually good at finding lesions before they become invasive cancer so a frequent screening schedule is often implemented.  If you have a mutation in CDH1, you might consider having your stomach removed to avoid diffuse gastric cancer (and possibly a BMX to lower risk of developing ILC).  And yes, if you have a BRCA mutation, you might consider BMX and oophorectomy.  In place of BMX, increased screening is offered, but as many of us know, invasive cancers can develop without being visible on imaging and/or in between images.  And there's no screening for ovarian cancer.  Yes, it's barbaric.
Posts.Title: 4 new genes confirmed to increase familial breast cancer risk cp418 have2laugh

Posts.Content: May 17, 2014 12:48PM lekker wrote: Different doctors have different post-op restrictions.  My plastic surgeon said that I couldn't lift my arms above shoulder level for 6 weeks.  I'm not a hairstylist but I would think the blow drying part would be the hardest as it requires both arms at once combined with strength and dexterity in a way that cutting and coloring might not (correct me if I'm wrong). Would you be able to hire an assistant - maybe a student who wouldn't cost much but would love the experience - to help you?  If you decide to go the tissue expander route, the later surgery to get your permanent implants generally has a shorter and easier recovery than the BMX, but you might need help then too.

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2017 11:22AM lekker wrote: It is possible that you developed a harmful gene mutation as you were developing in the womb - I think that's how all inherited mutations first start. That mutation develops in every cell in your body and can be passed on to your offspring. It is known as a de novo germline mutation - maybe try googling that term. Family history is only one factor when determining whether genetic testing is appropriate for an individual. Sometimes it's based on your ethnic background even if no one has developed cancer in your family. I'm assuming you've received a cancer diagnosis to be asking this - a personal history of cancer is another factor (diagnosed at a young age or certain rare types)
Posts.Title: Genetic Testing with No Family History? AnaMaria34 Lula73

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2013 12:45AM lekker wrote: Yes, I I meant you could have either mastectomy or lumpectomy + rads, then add on tamoxifen and then you have your recurrence risk as predicted by OncotypeDX. Mastectomy is considered equal to lumpectomy +rads for overall survival for many patients.
Posts.Title: does oncotype score take rads into account or just tamox? kika2013 lekker

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2014 04:50PM lekker wrote: Congratulations on your exchange!  I've had my implants for just over a year and I no longer walk around guarding my chest.   I don't remember exactly when I stopped worrying about it, but I was definitely cautious at first.  I was in a minor car accident 6 days after my exchange and I was ready to demand an mri to make sure the implants were ok!  Please give yourself some time - you're only a few days out from surgery.  You're smart to be careful at this point, but hopefully as you heal, you will think about it less and less.
Posts.Title: Protecting implants sbrownrigg sbrownrigg

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2013 06:17PM lekker wrote: The OncotypeDX score assumes you have completed acceptable surgical treatment - either lumpectomy + rads or mastectomy AND tamoxifen.
Posts.Title: does oncotype score take rads into account or just tamox? kika2013 lekker

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 12:33AM lekker wrote: When I searched for BIRADS 4/5 or 4-5, I couldn't find anything to explain it as 4c. From what I found, it seems to be a grouped score, like 1-3 and 4-5, with 1-3 being negative and no biopsy recommended and 4-5 considered positive and biopsy should be performed.  If that is correct, a summary rating of 4-5 would include cases that are 80% likely to be benign(4A) to > 95% chance of being malignant (5).  From a radiologist's perspective, I guess a 4 and a 5 aren't all that different in that they both should be biopsied, but from a patient's perspective, there's a huge difference.  I know I'm making assumptions here so please correct me if I'm wrong.
Posts.Title: BI-Rads 4/5 Should I be worried? Ohlord0626 marie5890

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 04:39PM lekker wrote: Consider asking your doctor for some pre-meds.  As long as it is approved in advance and the doctors are aware of what and how much you take, it should be fine.  I went to all 4 of my surgeries last year having already taken Xanax or Valium before I left my house.  It made the drive to the hospital and time in the prep area much more tolerable.

Posts.Title: Biopsy results-cystic and papillary apocrine metaplasia MelissaDallas MelissaDallas

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 03:46PM lekker wrote: Waiting for results is stressful.  Because you don't know the BIRADS score they gave your mass, there's no way any of us can tell you the odds.  As far as the significance of the immediate biopsy, that probably depends more on where you had it performed rather than the mass itself.  I have Kaiser and they asked to do an immediate biopsy on what turned out to be cancer, but they also asked to do an immediate biopsy on a lymph node a few months later that was a BIRADS 4 (less than 20% chance of malignancy).  I think at my facility, if it warrants a biopsy they try to do it right away regardless of the risk.  I know how awful waiting can be but for now try to distract yourself and get through the next few days knowing you've already done all you can do for now.  Please post again with your results - I will be looking for good news from you soon!  And if you do get bad news, know that we will be here to support you and answer your questions.
Posts.Title: Whirlwind of a day Allydp marie5890

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2014 12:42PM lekker wrote: I had a 5cm lump removed from my left breast when I was 17. The breast surgeon recommended removing it not because he thought it was cancer, only because he was concerned that it was so large that it might make imaging difficult as I got older. I went on to have two more lumps removed from my left breast when I was 29 and both turned out to be benign also. When I was 42, I was diagnosed with cancer in the right breast but it was unrelated.   We will not be able to tell you what your doctor is going to recommend - you will have to wait for that appointment.  If he/she does recommend surgery, it will most likely be an outpatient procedure.  I healed quickly from mine.  My mom was a great help during the whole process when I was a teenager.  Do you have someone to support you through this?  You're so young - I hope someone is taking great care of you!  Come back and let us know what the surgeon says.
Posts.Title: 17 Years Old, 4cm Lump? AnimalLoverJ Daisey4522

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 04:18PM lekker wrote: To be blunt, a 5 means that your mass appears to be malignant (greater than 95% chance so it's not definite, but likely). Until you know your pathology, there's really not much research you can do as there are many different types of breast cancer.  The one document I always endorse is here on BCO and it's a fill in the blank type form for understanding your pathology report.  I didn't read it until I received the call with my results but I had it printed out just in case. http://www.breastcancer.org/cms_files/47/Breastcancerorg_Pathology_Report_Guide_2014.pdf
Posts.Title: Whirlwind of a day Allydp marie5890
